Award.AwardTitle: AAAS Science & Technology Policy Fellowships at NSF, 9/1/2013 - 8/31/2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) will continue its collaboration in providing early and mid-career scientists and engineers with opportunities for professional development and public service via the AAAS Science and Technology Fellowship Program. Annually, Fellows are selected competitively and placed in offices throughout NSF, working on projects of mutual interest to the Fellow and the host directorate or office. By providing insight into the decision-making process, and learning about current issues affecting the scientific and engineering enterprise, Fellows will discover how NSF funds science, while providing scientific, engineering and educational input on issues relating to NSF's mission support of basic science and engineering research and education.

Fellows will work with staff involved in planning, development and oversight of agency programs in all fields of fundamental research. Assignments may involve significant interagency, congressional or international activity, as well as involvement with the National Science Board, NSF's policy-setting body. The program includes an orientation on executive branch and congressional operations, as well as a yearlong seminar program on matters involving science, technology and public policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
AAAS Science & Technology Policy Fellowships at NSF, September 1, 2017 to August 31, 2018

 

Overview: The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) placed 48 fellows at NSF through its Science & Technology Policy Fellowships program (STPF), over the period of September 1, 2017 to August 31, 2018. The broad objective is to build S&T leadership to support evidence-based policy and practice. AAAS provides policies and guidelines; conducts recruitment, selection and placement; programmatic management; administration of fellowship support; and implementation of professional development programs fellowship for the fellows at NSF. Now in its 45th year, STPF has extensive experience operating federal policy opportunities for scientists and engineers. AAAS administers the 1 to 2-year fellowships assignments, which augment NSF’s scientific and technical expertise. Fellows are selected through a rigorous merit review process. They are supported with a professional development program, including an orientation, seminars, skill-building workshops, career enhancement sessions, and gatherings to foster resource sharing and collaboration. Fellows learn through immersion in NSF host offices the processes for analyzing, developing, and implementing policies and programs that affect the national scientific agenda. They engage in a range of research programs, communication and education initiatives across NSF’s focus areas. Fellows contribute expertise, analytical talent, time, energy, and external perspectives and connections to NSF’’s core purpose to promote achievement and progress in science and engineering and enhance the potential for research and education to contribute to the Nation.

 

Intellectual Merit: The S&T Policy Fellowships are opportunities for professional development and public service, as part of the AAAS mandate to “advance science and serve society.” The aim is to foster evidence-based policy and practice by engaging scientists and engineers from a broad range of disciplines, backgrounds and career stages to directly contribute knowledge and analytical skills for well-informed federal policy actions; to learn first-hand about policymaking and implementation at the federal level; and to build leadership capacity for a strong S&T enterprise. AAAS has placed over 356 of its S&T Policy Fellows at NSF over 18 years. Annual reports of fellows’ activities highlight a wide range of projects and contributions to NSF initiatives, and a gain of knowledge, experience and networks that enable fellows to move into positions of greater influence.

 

Broader Impacts: Since 1973, more than 3,000 scientists and engineers have been through the program: ~2,300 in the executive branch, ~1,400 fellows in Congress, and the Judicial Branch program has placed three fellows at the Federal Judicial Center. Feedback attests that the experience enhances capacity to engage more effectively on a broad spectrum of issues with a range of audiences. Fellows’ supervisors also affirm the value of fellows’ contributions to host offices and NSF broadly. AAAS promotes the activities of its fellows via its website, an online newsletter, and through outreach presentations. Fellows at NSF have gone on to a broad range of positions in academia, government, nonprofits and industry. They carry into their future pursuits a deep understanding of U.S. government programs and initiatives and the many factors affecting policy.  STPF fellows have gained experience to comprehend the critical importance of research, applied science, and outreach that address societal challenges, support public policy, and contribute to the wellbeing of the nation and citizens around the world. Current and future cohorts of fellows create a growing network of STEM leaders to help improve policy outcomes and to mentor new generations of scientists and engineers with the skills to communicate and apply science to support improved policy.
